head.title: July 23-29; A Creeping Tale for $1 a Chapter

hedline.hl1: July 23-29; A Creeping Tale for $1 a Chapter

block.p: The horror writer Stephen King became the first major author to self-publish over the Internet when he released the first chapter of a serial novel called ''The Plant,'' about a vine that terrorizes a publishing house.

Mr. King's previous electronic book, the novella ''Riding the Bullet,'' drew 400,000 orders in the first 24 hours after Simon & Schuster published it in March. This time Mr. King is cutting out his publisher, hoping to break new ground for less commercially successful authors. Using a honor system, he is asking $1 for the first chapter and for each monthly installment. He will stop writing unless 75 percent of the downloaders pay, leaving fans in suspense.

The horror writer Stephen King became the first major author to self-publish over the Internet when he released the first chapter of a serial novel called ''The Plant,'' about a vine that terrorizes a publishing house.

Mr. King's previous electronic book, the novella ''Riding the Bullet,'' drew 400,000 orders in the first 24 hours after Simon & Schuster published it in March. This time Mr. King is cutting out his publisher, hoping to break new ground for less commercially successful authors. Using a honor system, he is asking $1 for the first chapter and for each monthly installment. He will stop writing unless 75 percent of the downloaders pay, leaving fans in suspense.

So far 41,000 copies of chapter one were downloaded the first day it appeared. That is far less than the initial demand for his novella, which had Simon & Schuster's advance marketing behind it. But it is still more than most titles sell in a year. Mr. King will post another tally this weekend. So far more than 75 percent of the readers are paying; Amazon.com is collecting. An envelope mistakenly arriving at Mr. King's office was addressed only: ''Stephen King, Rich Writer, Bangor, Maine.'' Inside was a check for $5. The return address: ''Satisfied Downloader.''
